<task>
build me a full ai agent that works with a CLI using python, add unit tests with full mockup for every component, the agent should be able to use "execute_command" tool, "write_to_file" tool and "edit_file_blocks", "read_file" and "list_files" all the tools must be using format in the chat xml and xml parser to catch them, the system should act as an autonomus agent. implement everything from start to finish and then at the end write a readme file with instructions to run it
</task>

<most_important_context>
# PLANNING:
- Ask your self the required questions.
- Think about the current step and the next step.
- If you are using  write_to_file tool you must write the entire content of the file, even if it hasn't been modified and write the entire implementation, no placeholders, leaving comments like // TODO: Implement edit functionality will hurt you as you might forget to implement it.
- Only do one tool call at a time you can't have multiple tool calls in one request.
- Remember that every tool you call has to go through the user first, you can't assume the outcome of a tool call, thus you must always wait for the user to confirm the result of the tool call before proceeding.
  * so if you are calling a tool you must wait for the user to confirm the content of the file before proceeding, the user might reject it or give you feedback that you need to address.
  * for example you called the read_file tool, you don't know the content of the file unless the user confirms and give you the content of the file in the next message.
  * for example you called the write_to_file tool, you don't know if the file was written successfully unless the user confirms it in the next message, the user can reject the content or give you feedback that you need to address.
  * If the user gives you feedback for a tool you must address it, his opinion is critical to the task completion.
  * user feedback is king, you can't assume the outcome of a tool call, you must always wait for the user to confirm the result of the tool call before proceeding.
  * this means that any early assumptions about the outcome of a tool call can lead to a failed task completion, you must always wait for the user to confirm the result of the tool call before proceeding.
  * remember that the user might reject the content of the file, you must address his feedback and try again.
  * remember that the user might give you feedback that you need to address, you must address his feedback and try again.
  * attempt completion shouldn't be eagrly called, only call it once the user confirms the result of the tool calls and you believe the task is completed.

# RUNNING A SERVER:
If you want to run a server, you must use the server_runner_tool tool, do not use the execute_command tool to start a server.

# WRITE_TO_FILE and EDIT_FILE_BLOCKS extra instructions:
You shouldn't never call read_file again, unless you don't have the content of the file in the conversation history, if you called write_to_file, the content you sent in <write_to_file> is the latest, you should never call read_file again unless the content is gone from the conversation history.
You should never truncate the content of a file, always return the complete content of the file even if you didn't modify it.
## Before doing a write of any sort (edit or full write) you must first write the following questions and answers:
- Do i have the last content of the file either from the user or from a previous read_file tool use or from write_to_file tool? Yes write_to_file | Yes read_file | Yes user provided | No i don't have the last content of the file
- Am i planning a to modify code blocks or rewrite / write a new file? (edit_file_blocks / write_to_file)
- what are the current ERRORS in the file that I should be aware of ?
- is the project on /frontend/[...path] or something like this ? if so remember to use the correct path /home/matan/code/test-3/kodu/ai-agent/frontend/[...path]

# IMPORTANT LINTING/ERRORS RULES:
Only address critical errors, ignore non-critical linting errors like warning or eslint basic errors like missing semicolon, var is not allowed, any is not allowed, etc...
Always address critical errors like missing imports, missing functions, missing classes, etc...
## Ask yourself the following questions when trying to debug or troubleshoot linting / server errors:
- Did i use code that is relvant to 2024 and not outdated code.
- Do i have any present errors in my code? (yes/no)
- If yes, what are the mission critical errors that I must fix? (list of errors)
- Is there any dependencies that I need to install? (yes/no)
- Is there any errors that are dependent on other files / errors? (yes/no)
- Is there any meaningful information from the browser logs (gotten from screenshot tool) that I should be aware of? (yes/no)
- Is this a package error ? (yes/no)
- Is this a syntax error? (yes/no)
- Is this a warning ? (yes/no) -> If yes, ignore the warning and continue with the task.
- If this is a package error, what is the package name and version that is causing the error?
- Can i fix this error by reading the latest documentation of the package? (yes/no) -> If yes, read the documentation using web_search tool.
By asking yourself these questions you will be able to fix the most critical errors in your code and make sure that you are not missing any dependencies or any other errors that are dependent on other files or errors.
It will make you more efficient and better at debugging your code and writing high quality code.

# closing notes:
- Remember to always ask yourself the required questions they will improve your efficiency and make sure you are on the right track.
- Remember to always ask the user for confirmation after each step.
- Remember that the year is 2024 and you should use the latest code practices, latest versions of packages and tools.
- Remember to try and finish the first POC of the task and then present it to the with the attempt_completion tool, if the user provides feedback, you can iterate on the POC and improve it.
- Writing something like // ... (keep the rest of the component JSX) or // your implementation here, is impossible, the user can't see the rest of the component JSX, you must provide the complete code, no placeholders, no partial updates, you must write all the code.
- You control the writing the user is a machine that can only understand the tools you provide, you must always respond with a tool call.
- if you edit an existing file, you must provide a diff of the changes you made, use parameter "kodu_diff" to provide the diff of the changes you made using the SEARCH/REPLACE methodology.
- before completing the task you must make sure there is no errors, no linting errors, no syntax errors, no warnings, no missing imports, no missing functions, no missing classes, etc...
- if there is any tests that you can run to make sure the code is working, you should run them before being confident that the task is completed.
- for example if you have test case that you can run to make sure the code is working, you should run them when you think the task is completed, if the tests pass, you can be confident that the task is completed.

import os
import re
from typing import Dict, Any, Optional, Callable
from xml.etree import ElementTree as ET
from dataclasses import dataclass
from colorama import Fore, Style, init

# Initialize colorama for cross-platform colored output
init()

@dataclass
class ToolResponse:
    success: bool
    message: str
    data: Optional[Any] = None

class Tool:
    def __init__(self, name: str, handler: Callable[..., ToolResponse]):
        self.name = name
        self.handler = handler

    def execute(self, params: Dict[str, str]) -> ToolResponse:
        try:
            return self.handler(params)
        except Exception as e:
            return ToolResponse(
                success=False,
                message=f"Error executing tool {self.name}: {str(e)}"
            )

class Agent:
    def __init__(self):
        self.tools: Dict[str, Tool] = {}
        self._register_default_tools()

    def _register_default_tools(self):
        """Register the default set of tools."""
        self.register_tool("execute_command", self._handle_execute_command)
        self.register_tool("write_to_file", self._handle_write_to_file)
        self.register_tool("edit_file_blocks", self._handle_edit_file_blocks)
        self.register_tool("read_file", self._handle_read_file)
        self.register_tool("list_files", self._handle_list_files)

    def register_tool(self, name: str, handler: Callable[..., ToolResponse]):
        """Register a new tool with the agent."""
        self.tools[name] = Tool(name, handler)

    def _parse_xml_command(self, command: str) -> tuple[Optional[str], Dict[str, str]]:
        """Parse an XML-formatted command string."""
        try:
            # Remove any leading/trailing whitespace
            command = command.strip()
            
            # Parse the XML
            root = ET.fromstring(command)
            
            # Get the tool name (tag name)
            tool_name = root.tag
            
            # Extract parameters from child elements
            params = {child.tag: child.text.strip() if child.text else '' 
                     for child in root}
            
            return tool_name, params
        except ET.ParseError as e:
            print(f"{Fore.RED}Error parsing XML command: {e}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
            return None, {}
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"{Fore.RED}Unexpected error parsing command: {e}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
            return None, {}

    def _handle_execute_command(self, params: Dict[str, str]) -> ToolResponse:
        """Handle the execute_command tool."""
        if 'command' not in params:
            return ToolResponse(False, "Command parameter is required")
        
        command = params['command']
        try:
            # Execute the command and capture output
            result = os.popen(command).read()
            return ToolResponse(True, f"Command executed successfully", result)
        except Exception as e:
            return ToolResponse(False, f"Error executing command: {str(e)}")

    def _handle_write_to_file(self, params: Dict[str, str]) -> ToolResponse:
        """Handle the write_to_file tool."""
        if 'path' not in params or 'kodu_content' not in params:
            return ToolResponse(False, "Both path and kodu_content parameters are required")
        
        try:
            # Ensure directory exists
            os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(params['path']), exist_ok=True)
            
            # Write content to file
            with open(params['path'], 'w') as f:
                f.write(params['kodu_content'])
            
            return ToolResponse(True, f"Successfully wrote to {params['path']}")
        except Exception as e:
            return ToolResponse(False, f"Error writing to file: {str(e)}")

    def _handle_edit_file_blocks(self, params: Dict[str, str]) -> ToolResponse:
        """Handle the edit_file_blocks tool."""
        if 'path' not in params or 'kodu_diff' not in params:
            return ToolResponse(False, "Both path and kodu_diff parameters are required")
        
        try:
            # Read the current file content
            with open(params['path'], 'r') as f:
                content = f.read()
            
            # Split the diff into blocks
            blocks = params['kodu_diff'].split('=======')
            
            # Process each search/replace pair
            for i in range(0, len(blocks)-1, 2):
                search = blocks[i].strip().replace('SEARCH\n', '', 1)
                replace = blocks[i+1].strip().replace('REPLACE\n', '', 1)
                content = content.replace(search, replace)
            
            # Write the modified content back to the file
            with open(params['path'], 'w') as f:
                f.write(content)
            
            return ToolResponse(True, f"Successfully edited {params['path']}")
        except Exception as e:
            return ToolResponse(False, f"Error editing file: {str(e)}")

    def _handle_read_file(self, params: Dict[str, str]) -> ToolResponse:
        """Handle the read_file tool."""
        if 'path' not in params:
            return ToolResponse(False, "Path parameter is required")
        
        try:
            with open(params['path'], 'r') as f:
                content = f.read()
            return ToolResponse(True, "File read successfully", content)
        except Exception as e:
            return ToolResponse(False, f"Error reading file: {str(e)}")

    def _handle_list_files(self, params: Dict[str, str]) -> ToolResponse:
        """Handle the list_files tool."""
        if 'path' not in params:
            return ToolResponse(False, "Path parameter is required")
        
        try:
            recursive = params.get('recursive', 'false').lower() == 'true'
            
            if recursive:
                files = []
                for root, _, filenames in os.walk(params['path']):
                    for filename in filenames:
                        files.append(os.path.join(root, filename))
            else:
                files = [f for f in os.listdir(params['path']) 
                        if os.path.isfile(os.path.join(params['path'], f))]
            
            return ToolResponse(True, "Files listed successfully", files)
        except Exception as e:
            return ToolResponse(False, f"Error listing files: {str(e)}")

    def process_command(self, command: str) -> ToolResponse:
        """Process a command string and execute the appropriate tool."""
        tool_name, params = self._parse_xml_command(command)
        
        if not tool_name:
            return ToolResponse(False, "Invalid command format")
        
        if tool_name not in self.tools:
            return ToolResponse(False, f"Unknown tool: {tool_name}")
        
        return self.tools[tool_name].execute(params)

    def run(self):
        """Run the agent in interactive mode."""
        print(f"{Fore.GREEN}AI Agent initialized. Enter commands in XML format or 'exit' to quit.{Style.RESET_ALL}")
        
        while True:
            try:
                command = input(f"{Fore.CYAN}Enter command: {Style.RESET_ALL}")
                
                if command.lower() == 'exit':
                    print(f"{Fore.YELLOW}Exiting...{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    break
                
                response = self.process_command(command)
                
                if response.success:
                    print(f"{Fore.GREEN}Success: {response.message}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    if response.data:
                        print(f"{Fore.WHITE}Output: {response.data}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                else:
                    print(f"{Fore.RED}Error: {response.message}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    
            except KeyboardInterrupt:
                print(f"\n{Fore.YELLOW}Interrupted by user. Enter 'exit' to quit.{Style.RESET_ALL}")
            except Exception as e:
                print(f"{Fore.RED}Unexpected error: {str(e)}{Style.RESET_ALL}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    agent = Agent()
    agent.run()
</kodu_content>
</write_to_file>

from unittest.mock import mock_open, patch, MagicMock
from src.agent import Agent, ToolResponse

@pytest.fixture
def agent():
    return Agent()

def test_parse_xml_command_valid():
    agent = Agent()
    command = """
    <execute_command>
        <command>ls -la</command>
    </execute_command>
    """
    tool_name, params = agent._parse_xml_command(command)
    assert tool_name == "execute_command"
    assert params == {"command": "ls -la"}

def test_parse_xml_command_invalid():
    agent = Agent()
    command = "invalid xml"
    tool_name, params = agent._parse_xml_command(command)
    assert tool_name is None
    assert params == {}

@pytest.mark.parametrize("tool_name,params,expected_success", [
    ("execute_command", {"command": "ls"}, True),
    ("execute_command", {}, False),
    ("write_to_file", {"path": "test.txt", "kodu_content": "content"}, True),
    ("write_to_file", {"path": "test.txt"}, False),
    ("read_file", {"path": "test.txt"}, True),
    ("read_file", {}, False),
    ("list_files", {"path": "."}, True),
    ("list_files", {}, False),
])
def test_tool_parameter_validation(agent, tool_name, params, expected_success):
    with patch('os.popen') as mock_popen, \
         patch('builtins.open', mock_open()), \
         patch('os.makedirs'), \
         patch('os.walk'), \
         patch('os.listdir'):
        
        mock_popen.return_value.read.return_value = "command output"
        response = agent.process_command(f"<{tool_name}>" + 
                                      "".join(f"<{k}>{v}</{k}>" for k, v in params.items()) +
                                      f"</{tool_name}>")
        assert response.success == expected_success

def test_execute_command_success():
    agent = Agent()
    with patch('os.popen') as mock_popen:
        mock_popen.return_value.read.return_value = "command output"
        response = agent._handle_execute_command({"command": "ls"})
        assert response.success
        assert response.data == "command output"

def test_write_to_file_success():
    agent = Agent()
    mock_file = mock_open()
    with patch('builtins.open', mock_file), \
         patch('os.makedirs'):
        response = agent._handle_write_to_file({
            "path": "test.txt",
            "kodu_content": "test content"
        })
        assert response.success
        mock_file().write.assert_called_once_with("test content")

def test_read_file_success():
    agent = Agent()
    mock_file = mock_open(read_data="test content")
    with patch('builtins.open', mock_file):
        response = agent._handle_read_file({"path": "test.txt"})
        assert response.success
        assert response.data == "test content"

def test_list_files_non_recursive():
    agent = Agent()
    with patch('os.listdir') as mock_listdir, \
         patch('os.path.isfile') as mock_isfile:
        mock_listdir.return_value = ["file1.txt", "file2.txt"]
        mock_isfile.return_value = True
        response = agent._handle_list_files({"path": "."})
        assert response.success
        assert response.data == ["file1.txt", "file2.txt"]

def test_list_files_recursive():
    agent = Agent()
    with patch('os.walk') as mock_walk:
        mock_walk.return_value = [
            (".", [], ["file1.txt"]),
            ("./subdir", [], ["file2.txt"])
        ]
        response = agent._handle_list_files({
            "path": ".",
            "recursive": "true"
        })
        assert response.success
        assert len(response.data) == 2
        assert "./file1.txt" in response.data[0] or "./subdir/file2.txt" in response.data[1]

def test_edit_file_blocks_success():
    agent = Agent()
    initial_content = "line1\nline2\nline3"
    expected_content = "line1\nnew_line2\nline3"

    with patch('builtins.open', mock_file):
        response = agent._handle_edit_file_blocks({

        })
        assert response.success
        # Check if write was called with the expected content
        mock_file().write.assert_called_once()

    agent = Agent()

<kodu_content># AI Agent CLI Tool

A Python-based AI agent that processes XML-formatted commands to perform various operations like file manipulation, command execution, and more. The agent provides a clean interface for executing tools through XML commands with proper parameter validation and error handling.

## Features

- XML-based command processing
- Built-in tools:
  - `execute_command`: Execute system commands
  - `write_to_file`: Write content to files
  - `edit_file_blocks`: Edit specific blocks within files
  - `read_file`: Read file contents
  - `list_files`: List files in directories
- Extensible tool system
- Comprehensive error handling
- Colored terminal output
- Full test coverage

## Installation

1. Clone the repository:
```bash
git clone <repository-url>
cd ai-agent
```

2. Create a virtual environment (recommended):
```bash
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
```

3. Install dependencies:
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

## Usage

Run the agent:
```bash
python src/agent.py
```

### Command Format

Commands should be formatted as XML with the tool name as the root element and parameters as child elements.

Examples:

1. Execute a system command:
```xml
<execute_command>
    <command>ls -la</command>
</execute_command>
```

2. Write to a file:
```xml
<write_to_file>
    <path>example.txt</path>
    <kodu_content>Hello, World!</kodu_content>
</write_to_file>
```

3. Read a file:
```xml
<read_file>
    <path>example.txt</path>
</read_file>
```

4. List files:
```xml
<list_files>
    <path>.</path>
    <recursive>true</recursive>
</list_files>
```

5. Edit file blocks:
```xml
<edit_file_blocks>
    <path>example.txt</path>
    <kodu_diff>
SEARCH
old content
=======
REPLACE
new content
    </kodu_diff>
</edit_file_blocks>
```

### Extending with Custom Tools

You can extend the agent with custom tools by registering new tool handlers:

```python
from src.agent import Agent, ToolResponse

agent = Agent()

def custom_tool(params: dict) -> ToolResponse:
    # Implement your tool logic here
    return ToolResponse(True, "Custom tool executed", "result data")

agent.register_tool("custom_tool", custom_tool)
```

## Testing

The project includes comprehensive unit tests using pytest. To run the tests:

```bash
pytest tests/
```

Or run a specific test file:

```bash
pytest tests/test_agent.py
```

## Project Structure

```
ai-agent/
 src/
    agent.py          # Main agent implementation
 tests/
    test_agent.py     # Unit tests
 requirements.txt      # Project dependencies
 README.md            # This file
```

## Dependencies

- pytest: Testing framework
- pytest-mock: Mocking support for pytest
- lxml: XML processing
- python-dotenv: Environment variable management
- colorama: Colored terminal output

## Contributing

1. Fork the repository
2. Create a feature branch
3. Commit your changes
4. Push to the branch
5. Create a Pull Request

## License

This project is licensed under the MIT License - see the LICENSE file for details.

<kodu_content># AI Agent CLI Tool

A Python-based AI agent that processes XML-formatted commands to perform various operations like file manipulation, command execution, and more. The agent provides a clean interface for executing tools through XML commands with proper parameter validation and error handling.

## Features

- XML-based command processing
- Built-in tools:
  - `execute_command`: Execute system commands
  - `write_to_file`: Write content to files
  - `edit_file_blocks`: Edit specific blocks within files
  - `read_file`: Read file contents
  - `list_files`: List files in directories
- Extensible tool system
- Comprehensive error handling
- Colored terminal output
- Full test coverage

## Installation

1. Clone the repository:
```bash
git clone <repository-url>
cd ai-agent
```

2. Create a virtual environment (recommended):
```bash
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate
```

3. Install dependencies:
```bash
pip install -r requirements.txt
```

## Usage

Run the agent:
```bash
python src/agent.py
```

### Command Format

Commands should be formatted as XML with the tool name as the root element and parameters as child elements.

Examples:

1. Execute a system command:
```xml
<execute_command>
    <command>ls -la</command>
</execute_command>
```

2. Write to a file:
```xml
<write_to_file>
    <path>example.txt</path>
    <kodu_content>Hello, World!</kodu_content>
</write_to_file>
```

3. Read a file:
```xml
<read_file>
    <path>example.txt</path>
</read_file>
```

4. List files:
```xml
<list_files>
    <path>.</path>
    <recursive>true</recursive>
</list_files>
```

5. Edit file blocks:
```xml
<edit_file_blocks>
    <path>example.txt</path>
    <kodu_diff>
SEARCH
old content
=======
REPLACE
new content
    </kodu_diff>
</edit_file_blocks>
```

### Extending with Custom Tools

You can extend the agent with custom tools by registering new tool handlers:

```python
from src.agent import Agent, ToolResponse

agent = Agent()

def custom_tool(params: dict) -> ToolResponse:
    # Implement your tool logic here
    return ToolResponse(True, "Custom tool executed", "result data")

agent.register_tool("custom_tool", custom_tool)
```

## Testing

The project includes comprehensive unit tests using pytest. To run the tests:

```bash
pytest tests/
```

Or run a specific test file:

```bash
pytest tests/test_agent.py
```

## Project Structure

```
ai-agent/
 src/
    agent.py          # Main agent implementation
 tests/
    test_agent.py     # Unit tests
 requirements.txt      # Project dependencies
 README.md            # This file
```

## Dependencies

- pytest: Testing framework
- pytest-mock: Mocking support for pytest
- lxml: XML processing
- python-dotenv: Environment variable management
- colorama: Colored terminal output

## Error Handling

The agent provides comprehensive error handling:

1. XML Parsing Errors:
   - Invalid XML format
   - Missing required parameters
   - Malformed tool commands

2. Tool Execution Errors:
   - File not found
   - Permission denied
   - Invalid command execution
   - File operation failures

3. Parameter Validation:
   - Required parameter checks
   - Parameter type validation
   - Path validation for file operations

All errors are properly caught and reported with meaningful messages in the terminal output.

## Development

To add a new tool:

1. Create a new tool handler function that returns a ToolResponse
2. Register the tool with the agent using register_tool()
3. Add appropriate tests in tests/test_agent.py
4. Update documentation as needed

Example of adding a new tool:

```python
def calculate_tool(params: dict) -> ToolResponse:
    if 'expression' not in params:
        return ToolResponse(False, "Expression parameter is required")
    try:
        result = eval(params['expression'])
        return ToolResponse(True, "Calculation successful", result)
    except Exception as e:
        return ToolResponse(False, f"Calculation error: {str(e)}")

agent = Agent()
agent.register_tool("calculate", calculate_tool)
```

1. Fork the repository
2. Create a feature branch
3. Commit your changes
4. Push to the branch
5. Create a Pull Request

<kodu_content>import os
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import Dict, Any
import json

@dataclass
class AgentConfig:
    history_size: int = 100
    log_level: str = "INFO"
    max_command_length: int = 10000
    tools_enabled: Dict[str, bool] = None
    custom_prompts: Dict[str, str] = None

    def __post_init__(self):
        if self.tools_enabled is None:
            self.tools_enabled = {
                "execute_command": True,
                "write_to_file": True,
                "edit_file_blocks": True,
                "read_file": True,
                "list_files": True
            }
        if self.custom_prompts is None:
            self.custom_prompts = {}

class ConfigManager:
    DEFAULT_CONFIG_PATH = "agent_config.json"

    @staticmethod
    def load_config(config_path: str = None) -> AgentConfig:
        """Load configuration from a JSON file or create default if not exists."""
        config_path = config_path or ConfigManager.DEFAULT_CONFIG_PATH

        if os.path.exists(config_path):
            try:
                with open(config_path, 'r') as f:
                    config_data = json.load(f)
                return AgentConfig(**config_data)
            except Exception as e:
                print(f"Error loading config: {e}. Using defaults.")
                return AgentConfig()
        return AgentConfig()

    @staticmethod
    def save_config(config: AgentConfig, config_path: str = None) -> bool:
        """Save configuration to a JSON file."""
        config_path = config_path or ConfigManager.DEFAULT_CONFIG_PATH

        try:
            config_data = {
                "history_size": config.history_size,
                "log_level": config.log_level,
                "max_command_length": config.max_command_length,
                "tools_enabled": config.tools_enabled,
                "custom_prompts": config.custom_prompts
            }
            
            with open(config_path, 'w') as f:
                json.dump(config_data, f, indent=4)
            return True
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error saving config: {e}")
            return False

<kodu_content>from typing import List, Dict, Optional
from dataclasses import dataclass, field
from datetime import datetime
import json
import os

@dataclass
class CommandHistory:
    timestamp: str
    command: str
    tool_name: str
    parameters: Dict[str, str]
    success: bool
    result: str

    @classmethod
    def create(cls, command: str, tool_name: str, parameters: Dict[str, str], 
               success: bool, result: str) -> 'CommandHistory':
        return cls(
            timestamp=datetime.now().isoformat(),
            command=command,
            tool_name=tool_name,
            parameters=parameters,
            success=success,
            result=result
        )

class HistoryManager:
    def __init__(self, max_size: int = 100, history_file: str = "command_history.json"):
        self.max_size = max_size
        self.history_file = history_file
        self.history: List[CommandHistory] = []
        self._load_history()

    def add_command(self, command: str, tool_name: str, parameters: Dict[str, str], 
                   success: bool, result: str):
        """Add a command to history."""
        history_entry = CommandHistory.create(
            command=command,
            tool_name=tool_name,
            parameters=parameters,
            success=success,
            result=result
        )
        
        self.history.append(history_entry)
        
        # Maintain max size
        if len(self.history) > self.max_size:
            self.history = self.history[-self.max_size:]
        
        self._save_history()

    def get_last_commands(self, count: int = 10) -> List[CommandHistory]:
        """Get the last n commands from history."""
        return self.history[-count:]

    def search_history(self, tool_name: Optional[str] = None, 
                      success: Optional[bool] = None) -> List[CommandHistory]:
        """Search history with optional filters."""
        filtered_history = self.history

        if tool_name is not None:
            filtered_history = [h for h in filtered_history if h.tool_name == tool_name]
        
        if success is not None:
            filtered_history = [h for h in filtered_history if h.success == success]

        return filtered_history

    def clear_history(self):
        """Clear the command history."""
        self.history = []
        self._save_history()

    def _save_history(self):
        """Save history to file."""
        try:
            history_data = [
                {
                    "timestamp": h.timestamp,
                    "command": h.command,
                    "tool_name": h.tool_name,
                    "parameters": h.parameters,
                    "success": h.success,
                    "result": h.result
                }
                for h in self.history
            ]
            
            with open(self.history_file, 'w') as f:
                json.dump(history_data, f, indent=4)
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error saving history: {e}")

    def _load_history(self):
        """Load history from file."""
        if not os.path.exists(self.history_file):
            return

        try:
            with open(self.history_file, 'r') as f:
                history_data = json.load(f)
            
            self.history = [
                CommandHistory(**entry)
                for entry in history_data
            ]
            
            # Ensure we don't exceed max_size
            if len(self.history) > self.max_size:
                self.history = self.history[-self.max_size:]
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error loading history: {e}")
            self.history = []

            print(f"Error saving history: {e}")

    def _load_history(self):
        """Load history from file."""
        if not os.path.exists(self.history_file):
            return

        try:
            with open(self.history_file, 'r') as f:
                history_data = json.load(f)
            
            self.history = [
                CommandHistory(**entry)
                for entry in history_data
            ]
            
            # Ensure we don't exceed max_size
            if len(self.history) > self.max_size:
                self.history = self.history[-self.max_size:]
        except Exception as e:
            print(f"Error loading history: {e}")
            self.history = []

            'ERROR': Fore.RED,

            record.levelname = f"{level_color}{record.levelname}{Style.RESET_ALL}"

            return f"{record.levelname} - {record.getMessage()}"

    def process_command(self, command: str) -> ToolResponse:
        """Process a command string and execute the appropriate tool."""
        self.logger.log_command_received(command)
        
        tool_name, params = self._parse_xml_command(command)
        
        if not tool_name:
            self.logger.error("Invalid command format")
            return ToolResponse(False, "Invalid command format")
        
        if tool_name not in self.tools:
            self.logger.error(f"Unknown tool: {tool_name}")
            return ToolResponse(False, f"Unknown tool: {tool_name}")
        
        if len(command) > self.config.max_command_length:
            self.logger.error("Command exceeds maximum length")
            return ToolResponse(False, "Command exceeds maximum length")
        
        response = self.tools[tool_name].execute(params)
        
        # Log and store in history
        self.logger.log_tool_execution(
            tool_name=tool_name,
            parameters=params,
            success=response.success,
            result=response.message
        )
        
        self.history.add_command(
            command=command,
            tool_name=tool_name,
            parameters=params,
            success=response.success,
            result=response.message
        )
        
        return response

    def update_config(self, **kwargs) -> bool:
        """Update agent configuration."""
        try:
            for key, value in kwargs.items():
                if hasattr(self.config, key):
                    setattr(self.config, key, value)
                    self.logger.log_config_change(key, value)
                    
                    # Apply changes that need immediate effect
                    if key == "log_level":
                        self.logger.set_level(value)
                    elif key == "history_size":
                        self.history.max_size = value
                    elif key == "tools_enabled":
                        self._update_enabled_tools()
            
            return ConfigManager.save_config(self.config)
        except Exception as e:
            self.logger.error(f"Error updating config: {e}")
            return False

    def _update_enabled_tools(self):
        """Update enabled/disabled tools based on configuration."""
        for tool_name, enabled in self.config.tools_enabled.items():
            if not enabled and tool_name in self.tools:
                del self.tools[tool_name]
                self.logger.info(f"Disabled tool: {tool_name}")
            elif enabled and tool_name not in self.tools:
                handler = getattr(self, f"_handle_{tool_name}", None)
                if handler:
                    self.register_tool(tool_name, handler)
                    self.logger.info(f"Enabled tool: {tool_name}")

    def get_history(self, count: Optional[int] = None, 
                   tool_name: Optional[str] = None,
                   success: Optional[bool] = None) -> str:
        """Get formatted command history."""
        if count is not None:
            history = self.history.get_last_commands(count)
        else:
            history = self.history.search_history(tool_name, success)
        
        return "\n".join(
            f"[{h.timestamp}] {h.tool_name}: {h.command} -> "
            f"{'Success' if h.success else 'Failed'}"
            for h in history
        )

    def run(self):
        """Run the agent in interactive mode."""
        print(f"{Fore.GREEN}AI Agent initialized. Enter commands in XML format or 'exit' to quit.{Style.RESET_ALL}")
        
        while True:
            try:
                command = input(f"{Fore.CYAN}Enter command: {Style.RESET_ALL}")
                
                if command.lower() == 'exit':
                    print(f"{Fore.YELLOW}Exiting...{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    break
                
                response = self.process_command(command)
                
                if response.success:
                    print(f"{Fore.GREEN}Success: {response.message}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    if response.data:
                        print(f"{Fore.WHITE}Output: {response.data}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                else:
                    print(f"{Fore.RED}Error: {response.message}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    
            except KeyboardInterrupt:
                print(f"\n{Fore.YELLOW}Interrupted by user. Enter 'exit' to quit.{Style.RESET_ALL}")
            except Exception as e:
                print(f"{Fore.RED}Unexpected error: {str(e)}{Style.RESET_ALL}")

    def _handle_utility_command(self, command: str) -> Optional[str]:
        """Handle utility commands that are not XML-formatted."""
        parts = command.lower().split()
        cmd = parts[0] if parts else ""

        if cmd == "help":
            return self._get_help_text()
        elif cmd == "history":
            count = int(parts[1]) if len(parts) > 1 else 10
            return self.get_history(count=count)
        elif cmd == "config":
            if len(parts) == 1:
                return f"Current configuration:\n{self.config}"
            elif len(parts) >= 3:
                key, value = parts[1], " ".join(parts[2:])
                try:
                    # Convert value to appropriate type
                    if value.lower() == "true":
                        value = True
                    elif value.lower() == "false":
                        value = False
                    elif value.isdigit():
                        value = int(value)
                    self.update_config(**{key: value})
                    return f"Configuration updated: {key} = {value}"
                except Exception as e:
                    return f"Error updating configuration: {e}"
        elif cmd == "tools":
            return "Available tools:\n" + "\n".join(
                f"- {name}: {'Enabled' if name in self.tools else 'Disabled'}"
                for name in self.config.tools_enabled.keys()
            )
        return None

    def _get_help_text(self) -> str:
        """Get help text for available commands."""
        return """
Available Commands:
-----------------
1. XML Commands:
   <tool_name>
       <parameter>value</parameter>
   </tool_name>

2. Utility Commands:
   - help                    : Show this help message
   - history [count]         : Show command history (default: 10)
   - config                  : Show current configuration
   - config <key> <value>    : Update configuration
   - tools                   : List available tools
   - exit                    : Exit the agent

Available Tools:
--------------
""" + "\n".join(f"- {name}: {tool.handler.__doc__ or 'No description'}"
                for name, tool in self.tools.items())

    def run(self):
        """Run the agent in interactive mode."""
        self.logger.info("Agent started in interactive mode")
        print(f"{Fore.GREEN}AI Agent initialized. Enter commands in XML format, 'help' for commands, or 'exit' to quit.{Style.RESET_ALL}")
        
        while True:
            try:
                command = input(f"{Fore.CYAN}Enter command: {Style.RESET_ALL}").strip()
                
                if not command:
                    continue
                
                if command.lower() == 'exit':
                    self.logger.info("Agent shutting down")
                    print(f"{Fore.YELLOW}Exiting...{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    break
                
                # Handle utility commands
                if not command.startswith('<'):
                    result = self._handle_utility_command(command)
                    if result:
                        print(f"{Fore.BLUE}{result}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                        continue
                
                # Process XML commands
                response = self.process_command(command)
                
                if response.success:
                    print(f"{Fore.GREEN}Success: {response.message}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    if response.data:
                        print(f"{Fore.WHITE}Output: {response.data}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                else:
                    print(f"{Fore.RED}Error: {response.message}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                    
            except KeyboardInterrupt:
                print(f"\n{Fore.YELLOW}Interrupted by user. Enter 'exit' to quit.{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                self.logger.warning("Command interrupted by user")
            except Exception as e:
                print(f"{Fore.RED}Unexpected error: {str(e)}{Style.RESET_ALL}")
                self.logger.error(f"Unexpected error: {str(e)}")

from src.config import AgentConfig, ConfigManager
import os
import json

@pytest.fixture
def config_file(tmp_path):
    config_path = tmp_path / "test_config.json"
    return str(config_path)

@pytest.fixture
def sample_config_data():
    return {
        "history_size": 50,
        "log_level": "DEBUG",
        "max_command_length": 5000,
        "tools_enabled": {
            "execute_command": True,
            "write_to_file": False
        },
        "custom_prompts": {
            "welcome": "Welcome to test agent"
        }
    }

def test_agent_config_defaults():
    config = AgentConfig()
    assert config.history_size == 100
    assert config.log_level == "INFO"
    assert config.max_command_length == 10000
    assert all(config.tools_enabled.values())
    assert config.custom_prompts == {}

def test_agent_config_custom_values():
    config = AgentConfig(
        history_size=50,
        log_level="DEBUG",
        max_command_length=5000,
        tools_enabled={"execute_command": True, "write_to_file": False},
        custom_prompts={"welcome": "Hello"}
    )
    assert config.history_size == 50
    assert config.log_level == "DEBUG"
    assert config.max_command_length == 5000
    assert config.tools_enabled["execute_command"]
    assert not config.tools_enabled["write_to_file"]
    assert config.custom_prompts["welcome"] == "Hello"

def test_config_manager_save_load(config_file, sample_config_data):
    # Create and save config
    config = AgentConfig(**sample_config_data)
    assert ConfigManager.save_config(config, config_file)
    
    # Verify file exists and content is correct
    assert os.path.exists(config_file)
    with open(config_file, 'r') as f:
        saved_data = json.load(f)
    assert saved_data["history_size"] == sample_config_data["history_size"]
    assert saved_data["log_level"] == sample_config_data["log_level"]
    
    # Load and verify config
    loaded_config = ConfigManager.load_config(config_file)
    assert loaded_config.history_size == sample_config_data["history_size"]
    assert loaded_config.log_level == sample_config_data["log_level"]
    assert loaded_config.tools_enabled == sample_config_data["tools_enabled"]

def test_config_manager_load_nonexistent(tmp_path):
    nonexistent_path = str(tmp_path / "nonexistent.json")
    config = ConfigManager.load_config(nonexistent_path)
    assert isinstance(config, AgentConfig)
    assert config.history_size == 100  # Default value

def test_config_manager_save_invalid_path():
    config = AgentConfig()
    assert not ConfigManager.save_config(config, "/invalid/path/config.json")

def test_config_manager_load_invalid_json(config_file):
    # Write invalid JSON
    with open(config_file, 'w') as f:
        f.write("invalid json content")
    
    config = ConfigManager.load_config(config_file)
    assert isinstance(config, AgentConfig)
    assert config.history_size == 100  # Default value

def test_agent_config_post_init():
    config = AgentConfig(tools_enabled=None, custom_prompts=None)
    assert isinstance(config.tools_enabled, dict)
    assert isinstance(config.custom_prompts, dict)
    assert "execute_command" in config.tools_enabled
    assert config.tools_enabled["execute_command"]

def test_config_manager_save_load_empty_config(config_file):
    config = AgentConfig()
    assert ConfigManager.save_config(config, config_file)
    loaded_config = ConfigManager.load_config(config_file)
    assert loaded_config.history_size == config.history_size
    assert loaded_config.log_level == config.log_level

if __name__ == "__main__":
    pytest.main([__file__])

<kodu_content>import pytest
from src.history import HistoryManager, CommandHistory
import json
import os
from datetime import datetime

@pytest.fixture
def history_file(tmp_path):
    return str(tmp_path / "test_history.json")

@pytest.fixture
def sample_command():
    return {
        "command": "<execute_command><command>ls</command></execute_command>",
        "tool_name": "execute_command",
        "parameters": {"command": "ls"},
        "success": True,
        "result": "command executed successfully"
    }

def test_command_history_creation():
    command = CommandHistory.create(
        command="<test></test>",
        tool_name="test",
        parameters={},
        success=True,
        result="test result"
    )
    
    assert isinstance(command.timestamp, str)
    assert command.command == "<test></test>"
    assert command.tool_name == "test"
    assert command.parameters == {}
    assert command.success
    assert command.result == "test result"

def test_history_manager_initialization(history_file):
    manager = HistoryManager(max_size=50, history_file=history_file)
    assert manager.max_size == 50
    assert manager.history_file == history_file
    assert len(manager.history) == 0

def test_add_command(history_file, sample_command):
    manager = HistoryManager(history_file=history_file)
    manager.add_command(**sample_command)
    
    assert len(manager.history) == 1
    assert manager.history[0].command == sample_command["command"]
    assert manager.history[0].tool_name == sample_command["tool_name"]
    assert manager.history[0].success == sample_command["success"]

def test_max_size_limit(history_file):
    manager = HistoryManager(max_size=2, history_file=history_file)
    
    # Add three commands
    for i in range(3):
        manager.add_command(
            command=f"<test>{i}</test>",
            tool_name="test",
            parameters={},
            success=True,
            result=f"result {i}"
        )
    
    assert len(manager.history) == 2
    assert manager.history[0].command == "<test>1</test>"
    assert manager.history[1].command == "<test>2</test>"

def test_get_last_commands(history_file):
    manager = HistoryManager(history_file=history_file)
    
    # Add multiple commands
    for i in range(5):
        manager.add_command(
            command=f"<test>{i}</test>",
            tool_name="test",
            parameters={},
            success=True,
            result=f"result {i}"
        )
    
    last_commands = manager.get_last_commands(3)
    assert len(last_commands) == 3
    assert last_commands[-1].command == "<test>4</test>"

def test_search_history(history_file):
    manager = HistoryManager(history_file=history_file)
    
    # Add commands with different tools and success states
    commands = [
        ("execute_command", True),
        ("write_file", False),
        ("execute_command", False),
        ("read_file", True)
    ]
    
    for tool_name, success in commands:
        manager.add_command(
            command=f"<{tool_name}></{tool_name}>",
            tool_name=tool_name,
            parameters={},
            success=success,
            result="test"
        )
    
    # Test filtering by tool name
    execute_commands = manager.search_history(tool_name="execute_command")
    assert len(execute_commands) == 2
    
    # Test filtering by success
    successful_commands = manager.search_history(success=True)
    assert len(successful_commands) == 2
    
    # Test combined filtering
    successful_execute = manager.search_history(
        tool_name="execute_command",
        success=True
    )
    assert len(successful_execute) == 1

def test_clear_history(history_file):
    manager = HistoryManager(history_file=history_file)
    
    # Add some commands
    manager.add_command(
        command="<test></test>",
        tool_name="test",
        parameters={},
        success=True,
        result="test"
    )
    
    assert len(manager.history) == 1
    manager.clear_history()
    assert len(manager.history) == 0

def test_history_persistence(history_file, sample_command):
    # Create a manager and add a command
    manager1 = HistoryManager(history_file=history_file)
    manager1.add_command(**sample_command)
    
    # Create a new manager with the same file
    manager2 = HistoryManager(history_file=history_file)
    assert len(manager2.history) == 1
    assert manager2.history[0].command == sample_command["command"]

def test_invalid_history_file():
    manager = HistoryManager(history_file="/invalid/path/history.json")
    assert len(manager.history) == 0
    
    # Should not raise an error when trying to save
    manager.add_command(
        command="<test></test>",
        tool_name="test",
        parameters={},
        success=True,
        result="test"
    )

def test_corrupt_history_file(history_file):
    # Write invalid JSON to history file
    with open(history_file, 'w') as f:
        f.write("invalid json content")
    
    manager = HistoryManager(history_file=history_file)
    assert len(manager.history) == 0

if __name__ == "__main__":
    pytest.main([__file__])

<kodu_content>import pytest
import logging
import os
from src.logger import AgentLogger
from colorama import Fore, Style
from unittest.mock import patch, MagicMock, call

@pytest.fixture
def log_file(tmp_path):
    return str(tmp_path / "test_agent.log")

@pytest.fixture
def logger(log_file):
    return AgentLogger(log_level="DEBUG", log_file=log_file)

def test_logger_initialization(log_file):
    logger = AgentLogger(log_level="INFO", log_file=log_file)
    assert logger.log_level == logging.INFO
    assert os.path.exists(log_file)
    assert len(logger.logger.handlers) == 2  # Console and file handlers

def test_logger_without_file():
    logger = AgentLogger(log_file=None)
    assert len(logger.logger.handlers) == 1  # Only console handler

def test_log_levels(logger):
    with patch('logging.Logger.debug') as mock_debug, \
         patch('logging.Logger.info') as mock_info, \
         patch('logging.Logger.warning') as mock_warning, \
         patch('logging.Logger.error') as mock_error, \
         patch('logging.Logger.critical') as mock_critical:
        
        logger.debug("Debug message")
        logger.info("Info message")
        logger.warning("Warning message")
        logger.error("Error message")
        logger.critical("Critical message")
        
        mock_debug.assert_called_once_with("Debug message")
        mock_info.assert_called_once_with("Info message")
        mock_warning.assert_called_once_with("Warning message")
        mock_error.assert_called_once_with("Error message")
        mock_critical.assert_called_once_with("Critical message")

def test_colored_formatter():
    formatter = AgentLogger.ColoredFormatter()
    
    # Create a mock record
    record = MagicMock()
    record.levelname = "ERROR"
    record.getMessage.return_value = "Test message"
    
    formatted = formatter.format(record)
    assert Fore.RED in formatted
    assert Style.RESET_ALL in formatted
    assert "Test message" in formatted

def test_log_tool_execution(logger):
    with patch('logging.Logger.info') as mock_info, \
         patch('logging.Logger.error') as mock_error:
        
        # Test successful tool execution
        logger.log_tool_execution(
            tool_name="test_tool",
            parameters={"param": "value"},
            success=True,
            result="Operation successful"
        )
        mock_info.assert_called_once()
        assert "test_tool" in mock_info.call_args[0][0]
        assert "Success" in mock_info.call_args[0][0]
        
        # Test failed tool execution
        logger.log_tool_execution(
            tool_name="test_tool",
            parameters={"param": "value"},
            success=False,
            result="Operation failed"
        )
        mock_error.assert_called_once()
        assert "test_tool" in mock_error.call_args[0][0]
        assert "Failed" in mock_error.call_args[0][0]

def test_log_command_received(logger):
    with patch('logging.Logger.debug') as mock_debug:
        command = "<test_tool><param>value</param></test_tool>"
        logger.log_command_received(command)
        mock_debug.assert_called_once()
        assert command in mock_debug.call_args[0][0]

def test_log_config_change(logger):
    with patch('logging.Logger.info') as mock_info:
        logger.log_config_change("log_level", "DEBUG")
        mock_info.assert_called_once()
        assert "log_level" in mock_info.call_args[0][0]
        assert "DEBUG" in mock_info.call_args[0][0]

def test_set_level(logger):
    with patch('logging.Logger.setLevel') as mock_set_level, \
         patch('logging.Logger.info') as mock_info:
        
        logger.set_level("ERROR")
        mock_set_level.assert_called_once_with(logging.ERROR)
        mock_info.assert_called_once()
        assert "ERROR" in mock_info.call_args[0][0]

def test_file_logging(log_file):
    logger = AgentLogger(log_file=log_file)
    test_message = "Test log message"
    logger.info(test_message)
    
    with open(log_file, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()
        assert test_message in content

def test_invalid_log_level():
    with pytest.raises(AttributeError):
        AgentLogger(log_level="INVALID_LEVEL")

def test_log_file_permission_error():
    with patch('os.makedirs', side_effect=PermissionError):
        logger = AgentLogger(log_file="/root/test.log")
        assert len(logger.logger.handlers) == 1  # Only console handler

def test_multiple_loggers_same_file(log_file):
    logger1 = AgentLogger(log_file=log_file)
    logger2 = AgentLogger(log_file=log_file)
    
    test_message = "Test message"
    logger1.info(test_message)
    logger2.info(test_message)
    
    with open(log_file, 'r') as f:
        content = f.read()
        assert content.count(test_message) == 2

def test_color_mapping():
    formatter = AgentLogger.ColoredFormatter()
    assert formatter.COLORS['DEBUG'] == Fore.BLUE
    assert formatter.COLORS['INFO'] == Fore.GREEN
    assert formatter.COLORS['WARNING'] == Fore.YELLOW
    assert formatter.COLORS['ERROR'] == Fore.RED
    assert formatter.COLORS['CRITICAL'] == Fore.RED + Style.BRIGHT

if __name__ == "__main__":
    pytest.main([__file__])

def test_utility_command_help(agent, mock_print):
    result = agent._handle_utility_command("help")
    assert result is not None
    assert "Available Commands" in result
    assert "XML Commands" in result
    assert "Utility Commands" in result

def test_utility_command_history(agent):
    # Add some commands to history
    agent.process_command("<execute_command><command>ls</command></execute_command>")
    result = agent._handle_utility_command("history 1")
    assert result is not None
    assert "execute_command" in result

def test_utility_command_config(agent):
    # Test config display
    result = agent._handle_utility_command("config")
    assert result is not None
    assert "Current configuration" in result
    
    # Test config update
    result = agent._handle_utility_command("config log_level DEBUG")
    assert result is not None
    assert "Configuration updated" in result
    assert "log_level" in result

def test_utility_command_tools(agent):
    result = agent._handle_utility_command("tools")
    assert result is not None
    assert "Available tools" in result
    assert "execute_command" in result

def test_command_length_validation(agent):
    long_command = "<test>" + "x" * 10001 + "</test>"
    response = agent.process_command(long_command)
    assert not response.success
    assert "exceeds maximum length" in response.message

def test_history_integration(agent):
    command = "<execute_command><command>ls</command></execute_command>"
    agent.process_command(command)
    
    history = agent.get_history(count=1)
    assert command in history
    assert "execute_command" in history

def test_config_update_integration(agent):
    assert agent.update_config(log_level="ERROR")
    assert agent.config.log_level == "ERROR"
    
    # Test invalid config update
    assert not agent.update_config(invalid_key="value")

def test_run_with_utility_commands(agent, mock_input, mock_print):
    mock_input.side_effect = ["help", "history", "config", "tools", "exit"]
    
    agent.run()
    
    # Verify help command output
    help_calls = [call for call in mock_print.call_args_list 
                  if "Available Commands" in str(call)]
    assert len(help_calls) > 0
    
    # Verify exit message
    exit_calls = [call for call in mock_print.call_args_list 
                  if "Exiting" in str(call)]
    assert len(exit_calls) > 0

def test_run_with_keyboard_interrupt(agent, mock_input, mock_print):
    mock_input.side_effect = KeyboardInterrupt
    
    agent.run()
    
    interrupt_calls = [call for call in mock_print.call_args_list 
                      if "Interrupted by user" in str(call)]
    assert len(interrupt_calls) > 0

def test_logger_integration(agent):
    with patch.object(agent.logger, 'log_command_received') as mock_log_command, \
         patch.object(agent.logger, 'log_tool_execution') as mock_log_tool:
        
        command = "<execute_command><command>ls</command></execute_command>"
        agent.process_command(command)
        
        mock_log_command.assert_called_once_with(command)
        mock_log_tool.assert_called_once()

def test_tool_registration_with_config(agent):
    # Test that tools are registered based on config
    assert "execute_command" in agent.tools
    
    # Disable a tool through config
    agent.config.tools_enabled["execute_command"] = False
    agent._update_enabled_tools()
    assert "execute_command" not in agent.tools
    
    # Re-enable the tool
    agent.config.tools_enabled["execute_command"] = True
    agent._update_enabled_tools()
    assert "execute_command" in agent.tools

if __name__ == "__main__":
    pytest.main([__file__])
